ldc_extent.charseq: Jesus Yeizon Deniz Mendoza, 18, told FBI agents he shot at the victims because he was "getting tired of waiting around and because the daughter laughed at him."

In the affidavit filed in Montana U.S. District Court Thursday, Mendoza admitted he shot three people with a 22-caliber rifle and then drove away from the scene in a car belonging to one of the victims.

In the affidavit filed in Montana U.S. District Court Thursday, Mendoza admitted he shot three people with a 22-caliber rifle and then drove away from the scene in a car belonging to one of the victims.
When officers arrived on scene, they saw the bodies of 50-year-old Jason Shane, Jr., of Pryor and his wife, 47-year-old Tana Rock Above Shane, lying face down on the ground.

Minutes before that, the surviving victim, their daughter, Jorah Shane, who is in her mid-20’s, told authorities that her mother came to the house and said she saw a man in need of help along the side of the road.

Minutes before that, the surviving victim, their daughter, Jorah Shane, who is in her mid-20’s, told authorities that her mother came to the house and said she saw a man in need of help along the side of the road.

Minutes before that, the surviving victim, their daughter, Jorah Shane, who is in her mid-20’s, told authorities that her mother came to the house and said she saw a man in need of help along the side of the road.
When the family pulled up to Mendoza's car, he allegedly pulled out a gun and told them to get out.
When she turned around, she saw her father lying on the road.
“J.B.S. stated that when she turned around, she saw the unknown male get into her car and drive off.
J.B.S. was able to yell for help, and she caught the attention of some individuals at the St. Charles Mission School.
Documents go on to say the driver got out of the car and walked towards Jorah’s parents.
“When J.B.S. saw her car coming back towards her, she got behind the wheel and drove away.
Court documents go on to say Jorah was able to drive herself a short distance to her sister’s home.
Her relatives then drove her to a nearby clinic for her injuries.
Her relatives then drove her to a nearby clinic for her injuries.
An alert was put out and Mendoza was taken into custody in Meeteetse, Wyo.
During an interview with FBI agents, Mendoza described the rifle he used and said it was still in the vehicle he was driving when he was arrested.
During a phone conversation with MTN News, Big Horn County Attorney Jay Harris said his office plans to open a full investigation into Mendoza's activities in the county prior to the homicide.

extent.charseq: Big Horn County Attorney Jay Harris
Big Horn County Attorney Jay Harris
man arrested in connection to the double homicide in Pryor this week is scheduled to make his initial appearance in federal court Friday afternoon.
man arrested in connection to the double homicide in Pryor this week is scheduled to make his initial appearance in federal court Friday afternoon.
Jesus Yeizon Deniz Mendoza, 18, told FBI agents he shot at the victims because he was "getting tired of waiting around and because the daughter laughed at him."

In the affidavit filed in Montana U.S. District Court Thursday, Mendoza admitted he shot three people with a 22-caliber rifle and then drove away from the scene in a car belonging to one of the victims.
The shooting happened on Pryor Gap Road Wednesday around 10 a.m.
When officers arrived on scene, they saw the bodies of 50-year-old Jason Shane, Jr., of Pryor and his wife, 47-year-old Tana Rock Above Shane, lying face down on the ground.

Minutes before that, the surviving victim, their daughter, Jorah Shane, who is in her mid-20’s, told authorities that her mother came to the house and said she saw a man in need of help along the side of the road.
As they walked away, Jorah, identified in the affidavit as "J.B.S." told agents she heard gun shots.
As she ran away, documents state she felt blood running down her face and felt a bullet hit her back.
The blood running down her face was the result of a bullet wound to her head.
“J.B.S. stated that when she turned around, she saw the unknown male get into her car and drive off.
J.B.S. stated that a car drove to her location, and she told the driver that she had been hurt,” documents state.
J.B.S. stated that a car drove to her location, and she told the driver that she had been hurt,” documents state.
Documents go on to say the driver got out of the car and walked towards Jorah’s parents.
“When J.B.S. saw her car coming back towards her, she got behind the wheel and drove away.
J.B.S. heard gunshots, but was not sure what the unknown male was shooting at," documents state.
Court documents go on to say Jorah was able to drive herself a short distance to her sister’s home.
Her relatives then drove her to a nearby clinic for her injuries.
Her relatives then drove her to a nearby clinic for her injuries.
An alert was put out and Mendoza was taken into custody in Meeteetse, Wyo.
During an interview with FBI agents, Mendoza described the rifle he used and said it was still in the vehicle he was driving when he was arrested.
During an interview with FBI agents, Mendoza described the rifle he used and said it was still in the vehicle he was driving when he was arrested.
During a phone conversation with MTN News, Big Horn County Attorney Jay Harris said his office plans to open a full investigation into Mendoza's activities in the county prior to the homicide.
